awd_titl_txt: GEM: Simulation Studies of Plasma Redistribution in the Ionosphere and Plasma Supply to the Magnetosphere in Geomagnetic Active Periods
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is focused on investigating how changes in the structure of the upper levels of the atmosphere can lead to changes in the plasma flowing out into the outer space.  During periods of significant space weather the circulation of plasma in the upper atmosphere can be dramatically changed, resulting in high density regions flowing over the polar cap that can lead to enhanced outflow of plasma flowing out along magnetic field lines into outer space.  These changes can impact radio communications through the ionosphere and may cause significant errors in positions derived from satellite based navigation systems.  The investigators will address this important topic through the development of a numerical model.  This model will be able to address how the outflow plasma relates to these density enhancements.  Success in modeling these interactions could potentially lead to improved numerical models for forecasting space weather.  In addition, this investigation will support training of a graduate student in computer programming and data analysis techniques. 

A major focus of this investigation will be simulation studies of plasma redistribution associated with the storm enhanced density (SED) and its possible counterpart plasmaspheric plume, polar cap tongues and patches, and enhanced ion outflow associated with such plasma redistribution during geomagnetic active times. The objective of the proposed studies is to expand the Dynamic Fluid Kinetic (DyFK) model to simultaneously follow multiple drifting individual flux tubes for simulating global plasma transport; to quantitatively understand physical processes that cause plasma redistribution and ion outflow; to provide quantitative measure of global ion outflow fluxes of multiple species necessary to understand effects of ionospheric plasma supply on the magnetospheric dynamics.

por.por_cntn:
The plasma space around the Earth from several hundreds of kilometers to several Earth?s radii is the region that connect the lower ionosphere and higher altitude magnetosphere. The continuous energy, momentum, and mass flow between lower ionosphere and higher altitude magnetosphere go through this middle region globally. While many numerical models have been developed to investigate structures and dynamics of the region below and above, no models exist to explore globally this middle region. The coupling of magnetosphere with ionosphere is established only at high latitudes by field-aligned currents or electric field mapping along the field lines and by ionospheric ion outflow. There are no models to couple the ionosphere and magnetosphere at lower and equatorial latitudes. Even the magnetosphere-ionosphere coupling at high latitudes, as well as coupling among different regions of ionosphere, must be via various waves instead of electrical currents or electrostatic fields.

We have used a first-of-its-kind two-dimensional global electromagnetic model of the inner magnetosphere-ionosphere/upper atmosphere system to investigate how the momentum is transferred from high-latitude ionosphere to low/equatorial ionosphere, in response to the magnetosphere disturbances. The simulation demonstrates that the global response of the ionosphere is caused by the coupling of the high-to-low latitude ionosphere through primarily the fast-mode magnetosonic wave (low frequency electromagnetic wave unique in the plasma) propagating from high latitude towards the equator. These discoveries reveal a completely new view of the ionosphere dynamics during the disturbed times. These new insights will eventually lead to new understanding of magnetic substorms, one of the phenomena that we still cannot explain its onset and subsequent evolution.

The simulation of the ionospheric ion transport to the magnetosphere we conducted reveals that localized enhancement of the plasma stream in the latitude region below the aurora during magnetic storm time has particular influence on the oxygen ions compared to the lighter hydrogen and helium ions. It has been shown by many studies that oxygen ions supplied by the ionosphere significantly influence the magnetosphere dynamics including the magnetic reconnection on the dayside magnetopause (a boundary separating Earth?s magnetosphere and solar wind) and in the magnetotail (a nightside magnetosphere region with elongated magnetic field lines). This finding on one aspect shows the importance of the global magnetosphere-ionosphere coupling by mass flow and the need of developing a global plasma transport model to fill the inner magnetosphere-topside ionosphere.

We have also developed a global hybrid particle simulation model for the inner magnetosphere-topside ionosphere by using advanced algorithms that allow smaller memory requirements and much faster access to the information on grids and of particle properties. The solution of Maxwell?s equations provides self-consistent description of the perturbation magnetic field and electrical current, so that the MHD waves are included in the description of the inner magnetosphere-topside ionosphere, an essential ingredient for the energy and momentum transfer in the space plasma.  The model provides capability to fill the gap between the global ionosphere and magnetosphere in terms of energy, momentum, and mass exchange. This is a next-generation model, once validation is completed, that will be integrated into the simulation framework from the Sun to the Earth?s surface.
